sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Angle-closure glaucoma, acute: (solution) instill 1 drop of 1% or 2% solution TOPICALLY into affected eye(s) up to 3 times over 30 minutes; pretreatment with secretory suppressant and hyperosmotic agent may be required to lower pressure below 50 mmHg
  • Angle-closure glaucoma, acute: with laser iridoplasty or iridomy, (solution) instill 1 drop of 4% solution TOPICALLY into affected eye(s) prior to procedure; afterwards, instill 1 drop of 1% solution TOPICALLY 4 times daily until iridotomy
  • Head and neck cancer - Radiation-induced xerostomia: initial, 5 mg ORALLY 3 times daily; titrate based on response and tolerability; usual maintenance dose is 15 to 30 mg daily; MAX 10 mg per dose
  • Miosis induction: (solution) instill 1 drop (or 2 drops 5 minutes apart) TOPICALLY into eye
  • Raised intraocular pressure: (gel) apply 0.5-inch ribbon of 4% ophthalmic gel TOPICALLY into lower conjunctival sac of affected eye(s) once a day at bedtime
  • Raised intraocular pressure, Associated with laser surgery; Prophylaxis: (solution) instill 1 drop (or 2 drops 5 minutes apart) TOPICALLY into eye(s) 15 to 60 minutes prior to surgery
  • Raised intraocular pressure, Associated with open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension: (solution) instill 1 drop TOPICALLY into affected eye(s) up to 4 times daily; strength of solution and frequency of instillation dependent on degree of pressure elevation and patient response; start at 1% strength in pilocarpine-naive; 2 minutes of punctal occlusion following instillation may be used to limit systemic exposure
  • Sjoegren's syndrome - Xerostomia: 5 mg ORALLY 4 times per day

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Miosis induction: prior to goniotomy or trabeculotomy, (solution) instill 1 drop of 1% or 2% solution TOPICALLY into eye 15 to 60 minutes prior to surgery
  • Raised intraocular pressure, Associated with open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension: (less than 2 years old) instill 1 drop of 1% solution TOPICALLY into affected eye(s) 3 times daily
  • Raised intraocular pressure, Associated with open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension: (2 years or older) instill 1 drop TOPICALLY into affected eye(s) up to 4 times daily; strength of solution and frequency of instillation dependent on degree of pressure elevation and patient response; start at 1% strength in pilocarpine-naive; 2 minutes of punctal occlusion following instillation may be used to limit systemic exposure

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• (oral) hepatic impairment, mild (Child-Pugh score of 5 to 6) no dose adjustment necessary
  • (oral) hepatic impairment, moderate (Child-Pugh score of 7 to 9) 5 mg ORALLY twice daily, regardless of indication, followed by dose adjustment for therapeutic effect and tolerability
  • (oral) hepatic impairment, severe (Child-Pugh score of 10 to 15) use not recommended

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Angle-closure glaucoma, acute
  • Head and neck cancer - Radiation-induced xerostomia
  • Miosis induction
  • Raised intraocular pressure
  • Raised intraocular pressure, Associated with laser surgery; Prophylaxis
  • Raised intraocular pressure, Associated with open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension
  • Sjoegren's syndrome - Xerostomia
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Mucositis following chemotherapy; Prophylaxis
  • Sjoegren's syndrome - Xerophthalmia

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• conditions in which miosis is undesirable (eg, acute iritis, narrow-angle glaucoma)
  • hypersensitivity to pilocarpine hydrochloride or any component of the product
  • pupillary block glaucoma (ophthalmic solution)
  • uncontrolled asthma (oral formulation)

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• cardiovascular disease, significant; pulmonary edema has been reported with high ocular doses; increased risk of reduced compensatory response to transient hemodynamic or rhythm changes; monitoring recommended (oral formulation)
  • cholelithiasis or biliary tract disease, known or suspected; complications (eg, cholecystitis, cholangitis, biliary obstructions) may occur due to gall bladder or biliary smooth muscle contractions (oral formulation)
  • cognitive or psychiatric disturbances; dose-related CNS effects may occur with cholinergic agonists (oral formulation)
  • driving at night and other hazardous occupations in poor illumination; decreased visual acuity and impaired depth perception resulting from visual blurring may occur with ophthalmic formulations
  • hepatic insufficiency, moderate; initial and maintenance dosage adjustments recommended (oral formulation)
  • hepatic insufficiency, severe (Child-Pugh score, 10 to 15); use not recommended (oral formulation)
  • nephrolithiasis; renal colic or ureteral reflux may occur due to increased ureteral smooth muscle tone (oral formulation)
  • pulmonary disease (eg, controlled asthma, chronic bronchitis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease requiring pharmacotherapy); increased airway resistance, bronchial smooth muscle tone, and bronchial secretions have been reported; monitoring recommended (oral formulation)
  • retinal disease or predisposition to retinal tears; retinal detachment has been reported; monitoring recommended (ophthalmic solution)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Pilocarpine: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Pilocarpine: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• Ophthalmic: Pilocarpine is a parasympathomimetic that directly stimulates cholinergic receptors. Through contraction of the iris sphincter muscle, increased tension on the scleral spur and opening of the trabecular meshwork spaces occurs to facilitate the outflow of aqueous humor. Intraocular pressure is reduced as outflow resistance is reduced.
  • Systemic: Pilocarpine is a cholinergic parasympathomimetic agent that exerts a broad spectrum of pharmacologic effects with predominantly muscarinic action, including stimulation of exocrine function. This stimulation results in increased secretion by the exocrine glands, including the salivary glands. Other exocrine glands, such as the sweat, lacrimal, gastric, pancreatic, and intestinal glands, as well as the mucous cells of the respiratory tract, may be stimulated.
  • Pilocarpine may have paradoxical effects on the cardiovascular system. Instead of the expected muscarinic effect of vasodepression occurring, pilocarpine may produce short-lived hypotension followed by hypertension. In addition, both bradycardia and tachycardia have been reported..
  • Gastrointestinal effects include smooth muscle stimulation of the intestinal tract that may result in increased tone and motility, spasm, and tenesmus. The tone and motility of the urinary tract, gallbladder, and biliary duct smooth muscle may be enhanced. .

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: 0.85 to 1.25 hours
  • Effect of food: rate of absorption decreased

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Renal: unchanged and degradation products; extent not described
  • Total body clearance, mild to moderate hepatic insufficiency: 30% lower

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• healthy volunteers: 0.76 to 1.35 hours
  • hepatic impairment, mild to moderate: 2.1 hours

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Ophthalmic
  • (solution) separate administration of other topical ophthalmic agents by at least 5 minutes
  • (solution) punctal occlusion for 2 minutes following instillation limits systemic exposure

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• (ophthalmic) reduction in intraocular pressure indicates efficacy
  • (oral) improvement in dry mouth symptoms indicates efficacy
  • (solution) fundus examination before therapy initiation

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patients using ophthalmic form may experience decreased visual acuity in dim light. Patient should avoid driving or other activities in poor illumination until drug effects are realized.
  • Ophthalmic form of this drug may cause stinging, burning, headache, myopia, reduced visual acuity, or retinal detachment. Systemic symptoms may occur, including sweating or gastrointestinal overactivity.
  • Oral form of this drug may cause headache, flushing, sweating, chills, nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, increased urinary frequency, rhinitis, or dose-related cardiovascular effects (eg, hypotension, hypertension, bradycardia, tachycardia).
  • Advise patient to report excessive sweating if unable to maintain adequate hydration.
  • Instruct patients using ophthalmic form on proper instillation technique.
  • Tell patient to apply ophthalmic gel at least 5 minutes after other glaucoma medication, if using.
